body: @b-slim or @nishantmonu51 could you please review this PR?
@leventov ok will take look at it.
@b-slim thank you!
LGTM
@jihoonson does #4550 contain this new three-dimensional system?
These issues seem to be related #1852 and #1840. It seems configuring the batch ingestion [`ignoreInvalidRows`](url) is the way to avoid this issue but we'll still be missing certain events.
@himanshug addressed comments

@qinzl1, this is really the shell that is foiling you (same problem as #4938). You can see it if you use echo to look at what the shell is doing to your input (try `echo '{"query":"SELECT COUNT(*) FROM data_source WHERE __time >= TIMESTAMP '2001-01-01 00:00:00'"}'`).

You can work around it by using shell escapes or by using curl's feature to read from a file with `-d @filename`.

@alexkappa, I tried reproducing this with the latest Druid and it seems to work ok. I used the wikipedia sample data that comes with the quickstart and edited one of the channel names to be a literal en dash, encoded in utf-8 as `e2 80 93`. It ingests fine and I can query if afterwards too.

```
dsql> select channel, count(*) from wikiticker where channel = U&'\2013' group by channel;
┌─────────┬────────┐
│ channel │ EXPR$1 │
├─────────┼────────┤
│ –       │      1 │
└─────────┴────────┘
Retrieved 1 row in 0.04s.
```

Is it possible you have some kind of encoding issue? If the en dash were encoded in utf-16 for some reason, that would explain this, since that would look like control characters to a utf-8 parser.
@himanshug could you please fix the conflict, and then feel free to merge yourself.
Thanks for the report. This looks related to #4883 and can be fixed after that patch is committed.

Thanks for your quick response.  There's no problem with empty tiers yet. However, our tests create tiers as part of their normal processing, and we'd like to treat these as temporary tiers:  Create a tier, use it for testing, and then delete the tier.  We're concerned that problems may appear in the future as undeletable tiers build up through testing.

When you say "could have a line," does that mean: In the future, such a line could be added; or, currently, such a line may exist?
@jihoonson could you please review?

@b-slim was thinking about the property and IMO it makes sense to have the property be like `druid.indexing.doubleStorage = double` or `druid.indexing.doubleStorage = float`. This makes it more explicit what is going on.
Marking WIP until I can add more tests.
@leventov would you merge this pr please?
@gianm let me know if this patch is enough.
Looks that CI failed.
@leventov given that this is incompatible and we haven't released 0.11.0 , is it possible to backport this to 0.11.0 ?
@himanshug thanks for review and merge, but this PR is tagged `Design Review` so it needed another one review from a committer
Anyway IMO it's too big and risky for backport at this point. I like the idea of making the next version 0.12 more, moreover I'm pretty sure there going to be more PRs that would break compatibility
E. g. somebody may want to implement #4888
@leventov thanks.

> I don't think that we can test both branches, so we need to choose one path.

@b-slim I understand that the new mode is only tested with this patch because we don't have much time. However, IMO, we need to add unit tests for legacy mode in the near future because it's the default mode in our next release. It means, without adding tests for legacy mode, our CI tests only non-default mode until 0.12.0. This will be a pain for us.

Ah, that system was a little bit changed. Instead of complicated preemptive/non-preemtive lock states, I added a new method ```doInCriticalSection()``` to TaskLockbox which guarantees that a given action is performed without lock preemption. I'll update this proposal shortly.
I hope in the nearest version . Druid will released Window Functions features .

@nishantmonu51 i think `io.druid.segment.DimensionHandler#getEncodedKeyComponentFromColumn` needs more attention.
ok, next release gets to be 0.12.0 then. My apologies, I dint realize that you tagged it for additional reviews.

Just want to note here that this PR appears to have changed behavior of `PolyBind.createChoiceWithDefault(..)` which is used in some custom extensions. On upgrade to 0.10.1, that led to error like...
```
"
Unknown provider[xx] of Key[type=com.MyClass, annotation=[none]], known options[yy]
  at io.druid.guice.PolyBind.createChoiceWithDefault(PolyBind.java:105) (via modules: com.google.inject.util.Modules$OverrideModule -> com.MyNamespaceExtractionModule)
  at io.druid.guice.PolyBind.createChoiceWithDefault(PolyBind.java:105) (via modules: com.google.inject.util.Modules$OverrideModule -> com.MyNamespaceExtractionModule)
  while locating com.MyClass
  ...
  ...
"
```

and following type of code...
```
        PolyBind.createChoiceWithDefault(
                 binder,
                 TYPE_PREFIX,
                 Key.get(MyExtractionCacheManager.class),
                 Key.get(OnHeapMyExtractionCacheManager.class),
                 "onHeap"
         ).in(LazySingleton.class);

```

was required to be replaced with

```

         PolyBind
                 .createChoiceWithDefault(binder, TYPE_PREFIX, Key.get(MyExtractionCacheManager.class), "onHeap")
                 .in(LazySingleton.class);
          PolyBind
                 .optionBinder(binder, Key.get(MyExtractionCacheManager.class))
                 .addBinding("onHeap")
                 .to(OnHeapMyExtractionCacheManager.class)
                 .in(LazySingleton.class);



```

@leventov does that look expected ?
@himanshug it looks like there is a problem with `createChoiceWithDefault()`

@kevinconaway Sorry, I somehow missed your comment earlier. Yeah, failing fast is fine in this case, I think. It is ultimately a server misconfiguration and client alone cannot do much about it.

@himanshug @leventov

@jihoonson thanks, addressed comments
integration tests are able to run with this patch now, but the latest run hit travis' job time limit
Travis CI passes with this, if we're still having problems tomorrow with the integration tests related to the java 8 install, this will fix the issues for now.

My bad. I've been launching 2 Coordinators and 2 Overlords with embedded Derby on 2 different hosts. So I had 2 versions of metadata storages :D After I changed the dataspec I also restarted all nodes. Apparently cluster's "head" switched to another node and started using another metadata storage.
These are full logs from server https://gist.github.com/l15k4/ff4e61376bf5367e707ddfd1fc15c287

I compared the logs at 0.9.2 and 0.10.1 and they are identical ... the `descriptor.json` at s3 too...

Could this be caused by different hadoop-client versions `2.3.0` -> `2.7.3` ?
So we can get CI working for the _other_ backports.
@a2l007 could you please update this patch to be based off the most recent 0.11.0 branch? It has #4978 in it, which should help CI pass.
@leventov does this need to be included in 0.11.0? (you have marked it as such but I don't see a reason why in the PR description)

@gianm it's a bug that makes `cachingCost` balancer strategy absolutely dysfunctional. BTW all users are encouraged to try `cachingCost` in production in 0.11.0 because the plan is that it's going to become the default balancer strategy in the next release. It's going to replace `cost`, i. e. `cost` and `cachingCost` will mean the same.

Thanks for the explanation. Let's then also make sure that the encouragement to try out `cachingCost` makes it into the release notes for 0.11.0. I'll mark this issue as "Release notes" as a reminder.
@gianm better #4731 because it has explanations

Some suggestions:

- Double check for any PRs that landed in the 0.11.0 branch but are not marked as 0.11.0. Since the recent decision to move to time-based releases, we have not been necessarily marking all PRs with the milestone (just "important/blocker" ones). So the best way to find them is trawling the git commit history for the 0.11.0 branch.
- Put TLS & Authentication/authorization extension points next to each other as the first two points, and insert some language in the preamble ("Major new features include…") about how this release is a big deal from a security perspective.
- The "Updating from 0.10.1" section should have something about the setting introduced in #4944.
- The "Updating from 0.10.1" section is scarily long, but many of the points are actually not that big of a deal. I'd suggest keeping the ones that _are_ a big deal in their own subsections (like they are now) but grouping together all the minor ones into an "other" subsection. Also group together all the ones that only apply to extension authors.
- There's a "Placeholder" in the notes for some reason.
Suggested to mention the new balancer strategy as `druid.coordinator.balancer.strategy=cachingCost`, because otherwise it's not very easy to find in docs how to configure it

Btw, for "Authentication/authorization extension points" I think it'd be good to add language making it clear that this version does include one implementation (Kerberos) with a link to instructions on how to use that one.

The problem here is, that the `tuningConfig` is ignored in this case :-/ So I added `druid/_common/core-site.xml` with : 
```
<configuration>
  <property>
    <name>fs.s3.impl</name>
    <value>org.apache.hadoop.fs.s3a.S3AFileSystem</value>
  </property>

  <property>
    <name>fs.s3n.impl</name>
    <value>org.apache.hadoop.fs.s3a.S3AFileSystem</value>
  </property>

  <property>
    <name>fs.s3a.access.key</name>
    <value>${COMMON_DRUID_S3_ACCESSKEY}</value>
  </property>

  <property>
    <name>fs.s3a.secret.key</name>
    <value>${COMMON_DRUID_S3_SECRETKEY}</value>
  </property>

  <property>
    <name>fs.s3a.endpoint</name>
    <value>s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com</value>
  </property>

  <property>
    <name>com.amazonaws.services.s3.enableV4</name>
    <value>true</value>
  </property>
</configuration>
```

Adding `core-site.xml` with : 
```
<configuration>
  <property>
    <name>fs.s3.impl</name>
    <value>org.apache.hadoop.fs.s3native.NativeS3FileSystem</value>
  </property>

  <property>
    <name>fs.s3n.impl</name>
    <value>org.apache.hadoop.fs.s3native.NativeS3FileSystem</value>
  </property>

  <property>
    <name>fs.s3n.access.key</name>
    <value>${COMMON_DRUID_S3_ACCESSKEY}</value>
  </property>

  <property>
    <name>fs.s3n.secret.key</name>
    <value>${COMMON_DRUID_S3_SECRETKEY}</value>
  </property>
</configuration>
```
Doesn't help either, it is not picked up...

For this S3N configuration: 
```
<configuration>
  <property>
    <name>fs.s3.impl</name>
    <value>org.apache.hadoop.fs.s3native.NativeS3FileSystem</value>
  </property>

  <property>
    <name>fs.s3n.impl</name>
    <value>org.apache.hadoop.fs.s3native.NativeS3FileSystem</value>
  </property>

  <property>
    <name>fs.s3n.access.key</name>
    <value>${COMMON_DRUID_S3_ACCESSKEY}</value>
  </property>

  <property>
    <name>fs.s3n.secret.key</name>
    <value>${COMMON_DRUID_S3_SECRETKEY}</value>
  </property>
</configuration>
```

I think you'd need to set "fs.s3n.awsAccessKeyId" instead of "fs.s3n.access.key" and        "fs.s3n.awsSecretAccessKey" instead of "fs.s3n.secret.key"
@drcrallen @himanshug any further comments?
Thanks @jon-wei, I will try it out. But why doesn't it pick up the `tuningConfig` as it does in `0.9.2` ? We don't use hadoop at all, we just use it for s3 in/out .

Hi @gianm,

Thanks for looking into this issue! 

I am not entirely sure I understand the encoding `e2 80 93`. I typically end up with a `\u2013` when serialising to JSON. With a little googling I could repeat that with [this online utf8 encoder/decoder](https://mothereff.in/utf-8#%E2%80%93) so I have the feeling I am misunderstanding something.

@jihoonson more comments here?

What I mean is that the character `\u2013` could be encoded in different ways. It could be encoded in utf-8 as three bytes, `e2 80 93` or it could be encoded in utf-16 as two bytes, `20 13`. JSON calls for utf-8 encoding and that's what Druid expects.

My guess is that your en dash is (incorrectly) encoded in utf-16, since the first byte `20` would be interpreted by a JSON decoder as a control character, which matches up with the error you got.
Opening your file in a hex editor, or using hexdump, should make it clear how the character is encoded.

> Remote caching on historicals, while there is no caching on brokers, meets only one point ("smooth transition") and it feels like to little for me, to justify using remote cache at all.

It is also used when you have same segment replicated on multiple historicals, second query for that segment might land on either historicals and they would be able to utilize the cache.

wondering whether you are facing a specific problem and trying to fix that ? if historical received a query and result for the segment in the cache then it should get it from cache. broker shouldn't have sent the query to historical if it did not need that.
Implementation looks good to me. But, can you describe specific use case, that you have, for which this is being added?

@himanshug We run Druid instances in [Marathon](https://mesosphere.github.io/marathon/). Using this hook, we added dimensions which reflect Marathon app name and instance id, in our proprietary extension.

@himanshug yes, we have a lot of memcached timeouts on historicals, and then query timeouts as well. Despite memcached connection library is configured to wait for no more than 500ms, I suspect that it doesn't actually follow this restriction, i. e. queries may wait for response from memcached for longer. It doesn't make sense, given 99% of the time the answer from memcached is going to be "not found"

@gianm 

> emitter/buffers/allocated seems like it would be easier to monitor for problems as a gauge rather than delta metric. (You could check if its avg value is too high)

The workflow is that if a buffer is failed to be emitted, it goes to a separate "fail queue" (reflected by `emitter/buffers/failed`), and if it is successfully emitted from there, it doesn't return to the `reuseQueue`. So the number of allocated buffers could grow indefinitely. I would keep it a delta metric, `emitter/buffers/failed` above zero could also allow to spot problem.

Also, I fixed description of `emitter/buffers/reuseQueue`, it was not correct.

> Btw, do you suspect bugs in the emitter that caused you to add these metrics?

I would say not bugs, but the way the code is written, may lead to uncontrolled growth of the amount of buffers, if there are network problems with emitting. We are exploring that at the moment.

> How do these metrics get emitted if the emitter is not working right?

Thanks, I didn't think about this before. At least HttpPostEmitter logs something when it couldn't emit a buffer, so it could be spotted in logs. Also in case of network problems, emitting old events doesn't block the new events, so if problems are gone, we could see new events. But in this case the information about problems could be lost, if we don't have gauge `emitter/buffers/allocated` metric. So I think I'm going to change it's to gauge indeed.
@himanshug pushed a new commit addressing your comments.
